abstract.p: Prof Gary Chaison letter scoress method by which union demonstrated majority support for right to represent Verizon's nonunion wireless workers (Aug 22 article)

block.p: Your analysis of the Verizon strike (Business Day, Aug. 22) glossed over a crucial feature of the dispute: the unions were adamant and successful in negotiating a simple and fast way (the tally of membership cards) to demonstrate majority support for the right to represent Verizon's nonunion wireless workers.

Your analysis of the Verizon strike (Business Day, Aug. 22) glossed over a crucial feature of the dispute: the unions were adamant and successful in negotiating a simple and fast way (the tally of membership cards) to demonstrate majority support for the right to represent Verizon's nonunion wireless workers.

This adds to the evidence that unions have lost faith in the legally prescribed method for organizing workers -- secret ballot elections conducted by the National Labor Relations Board. Laws meant to further workers' rights to union representation need to be repaired or replaced. Why haven't we heard specific suggestions for labor law reform, not just the platitudes about helping workers and working families, from George W. Bush and Al Gore?
The writer is a professor of industrial relations at Clark University.
